issues.title: QA DICOM Web Viewer i18nLocalesPath Integration
Support imaging with multiple images (CT or MRI)
issues.body: The issue is that the current dicom mechanism only supports 1 image. This is great for xrays. However, it sounds like this will get much more complicated for imaging with multiple images (such as a CT or MRI).

issues.title: Document reference isn't stored in the database when a patient has a very large pid
issues.body:
This bug is minor because it can only really happen from the use of another tool connected to the OpenEMR database (patient demo generator, for example, which has been patched), but basically when a patient `pid` is huge (e.g.: 99999999999), certain `foreign_id` fields in tables that point back to the `patient_data` table can't hold the value. This is the case with the `documents` table.

This would be a good first issue for someone looking to explore the code.

issues.title: Adding acl group to user on create/edit user
issues.body:
Hi.
Currently users that don't have the 'Administration ACL' permission can't add/edit user's acl group. 
This means that if a user has permissions to create users but does not have Administration ACL permission he can only create users without any permissions, which is pretty useless.
We think that the ability to add/edit a user's acl group (in the add/edit users screen - not in the acl screen) should not be part of the 'Administration ACL' permission but rather part of the 'Users/Groups/Logs Administration' permission.

pull_requests.title: Zbig01 backup update 1
pull_requests.body:
User interface improvements to the Administration->Backup along with a help script. Taken from the following PR:
https://github.com/openemr/openemr/pull/1235

Also fixes to the commandline restore script:
"The first thing that I noted was that whatever your database and openemr installation was called the recovered one would be called openemr. Secondly the restore script assumed the Web root directory to be /var/www/
I order to fix these problems I created a text file that contains the installation data, openemr-setup.txt, and modified the restore script to accept these values as needed. This now results in the recovered installation to be identical in all respects to the original. In addition the restore script is now included in the emr_backup.tar which now contains 2 archives and two files - openemr-setup.txt and restore."

Demo is here:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Epsilon_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

Hi garcianc,

The OpenEMR project does not use github to pull in code to the codebase (and none of the developers except myself will see these pull requests). To get the code reviewed and into the codebase, you need to post a link to your github commit(s) or branch(es) on the sourceforge developer forum:

Check out our developer documentation here:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/OpenEMR_Wiki_Home_Page#Developer_Manuals

Regarding placing new indexes, you add them to both the database.sql and 4_1_1-to-4_1_2_upgrade.sql scripts. Your database.sql looks ok. This is how would do it in the upgrade script (note that these comments are actually functions utilized by the upgrade scripts; see the top of the upgrade script for the function descriptions):

```
#IfNotIndex form_encounter encounter
CREATE INDEX encounter on form_encounter (encounter);
#EndIf

#IfNotIndex form_encounter encounter_date
CREATE INDEX encounter_date on form_encounter (date); 
#EndIf
```

thanks,
-brady

review_comments.body:
Hi Art,

Need to keep your master branch clean or things will go to hell (I am exaggerating a bit, of course :) ).

Don't merge into your master like this. Then you won't know what you are testing on on all the branches based on this. To clean up, suggest on your local repo doing following:

```
# Go to master
git checkout master
# Reset your master to the commit prior to the merge commit
git reset --hard 24978cf2557ab527e83d7c58c6f1e48c6c8e842d
# Now overwrite your local branch master to your github repo (I am assuming you call it 'origin')
git push origin +master
```

And in future, when you want to feed your master from official codebase, follow these instructions:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Git_for_dummies#Step_3:_Feeding_your_repository

-brady

pull_requests.title: Self checkin feature
pull_requests.body:
# Patient Self Checkin Feature

This feature allows patients to check themselves in for their appointment using a touch screen kiosk, for example this - (http://www.jayex.com/images/slideshows/patient-check-in//17in-kiosks.jpg) 
However, OpenEMR is web based - all you need is a web browser, so a spare iPad/tablet could be wall mounted and used for the checking in of patients.

The feature is found at http(s)://YourServerHere/portal/patient_self_checkin/

**Why is it useful?**

It frees up reception staff to answer the phone, deal with prescription queries etc. When the patient checks themself in, the same features are performed as when the reception checks them in. That is, the encounter is created, the status is updated to (@ Arrived) and the [flow board](http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Patient_Flow_Board) also reflects the time they checked in and starts the clock counting.

**Checks performed**
In an effort to ensure my code is as reliable as possible, I have performed the following checks

- The same patient cannot check in twice
- Only patients with appointments today can check in
- If a patient has 2 appointments on the same day, nothing untoward happens, they are simply checked in for both simultaneously. The only time I can think of this happening is, for example, if they have an appointment with the Dr and then the nurse, say for phlebotomy services. Maybe the community can clarify for me?
-  This feature can be enabled and disabled via the global preferences pane.

**Documentation**
I am working on docs - just let me know where to send them/post them. Not sure if they need to go in the wiki/user guide or whereever?

**Screenshots**
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/x8te9ba23c5iaa0/AAComgUSKMv5bvyG80rBMWcHa?dl=0 

**Demo**
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Gamma_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

commit_comments.body:
Also Needed to handle the cases where sortby and sortorder are passed in the request, but are empty.

I know this was already pulled into the master.  Just explaining what was going on here for historical purpose.

split is deprecated
http://php.net/manual/en/function.split.php
Should use either explode or preg_split instead.
I believe that
$mods = preg_split("/[: ]/",trim($this->procs[$prockey]['modifier']));
will actually make it so that both ":" or space will work.  That way we also don't break this for yourika who provided guidance on this.

Even though ":" was documented as the delimiter to use for multiple modifiers, it really wasn't correct since doing so would have resulted in incorrect CMS1500 claims.  This should handle both scenarios, where if a practice was primarily using CMS1500 and using space, their X12 claims would now work, and if they were using colon for X12 claims, their CMS1500 would now be valid.
It would be nice if the comments were consistent with the code. (144 chars limit specified in comment, but 255 in code)
Two a's in Start?

Not a big deal, but when people who have already patched/upgraded before upgrade again they are going to have both the pid index AND pid_encounter index which will be redundant .  Won't break anything, but MySQL will have to work ever so slightly harder  and use more space than if only the one index exist.

issue_comments.body: Ah, I thought Github was the primary now. I will pay better attention next time.

The problem only occurs when you're using the new CMS1500 (02/12) and an old claim.  OpenEMR now includes the code type with the diagnosis when justifying a code.  When the code type is included, it is stored in $code_data[0], and the actual code is stored in $code_data[1].  When the type is not included, the actual code is stored in $code_data[0].  When using the new CMS1500 (and therefore not stripping periods) OpenEMR would still look for the code in $code_data[1].

You'll also note that this throws off the diagnosis pointer.

Before Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731610/c2754c8c-c62f-11e3-9e14-764d1605ad66.png)

After Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731620/d85c1256-c62f-11e3-99f5-e047f8fed314.png)

@bradymiller I added the styling back to the HTML file so that users would be able to modify it easily. The forcing of UTF-8 does nothing, as when the page is served over HTTP the `charset` attribute in the HTTP `Content-Type` response dictates what encoding to use. The UTF-8 encoding would only be forced when that page is saved and accessed locally.
@bradymiller Fixed that error, I had just styled it wrong. Everything else looks good compared to the to Dev Demo.
@bradymiller Anytime! Does this pull request get merged too?
Nope, it just gets closed.

issues.title: Document reference isn't stored in the database when a patient has a very large pid
issues.body:
This bug is minor because it can only really happen from the use of another tool connected to the OpenEMR database (patient demo generator, for example, which has been patched), but basically when a patient `pid` is huge (e.g.: 99999999999), certain `foreign_id` fields in tables that point back to the `patient_data` table can't hold the value. This is the case with the `documents` table.

This would be a good first issue for someone looking to explore the code.

issues.title: Adding acl group to user on create/edit user
issues.body:
Hi.
Currently users that don't have the 'Administration ACL' permission can't add/edit user's acl group. 
This means that if a user has permissions to create users but does not have Administration ACL permission he can only create users without any permissions, which is pretty useless.
We think that the ability to add/edit a user's acl group (in the add/edit users screen - not in the acl screen) should not be part of the 'Administration ACL' permission but rather part of the 'Users/Groups/Logs Administration' permission.

I order to fix these problems I created a text file that contains the installation data, openemr-setup.txt, and modified the restore script to accept these values as needed. This now results in the recovered installation to be identical in all respects to the original. In addition the restore script is now included in the emr_backup.tar which now contains 2 archives and two files - openemr-setup.txt and restore."

Demo is here:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Epsilon_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

pull_requests.title: Self checkin feature
pull_requests.body:
# Patient Self Checkin Feature

This feature allows patients to check themselves in for their appointment using a touch screen kiosk, for example this - (http://www.jayex.com/images/slideshows/patient-check-in//17in-kiosks.jpg) 
However, OpenEMR is web based - all you need is a web browser, so a spare iPad/tablet could be wall mounted and used for the checking in of patients.

The feature is found at http(s)://YourServerHere/portal/patient_self_checkin/

**Why is it useful?**

It frees up reception staff to answer the phone, deal with prescription queries etc. When the patient checks themself in, the same features are performed as when the reception checks them in. That is, the encounter is created, the status is updated to (@ Arrived) and the [flow board](http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Patient_Flow_Board) also reflects the time they checked in and starts the clock counting.

**Checks performed**
In an effort to ensure my code is as reliable as possible, I have performed the following checks

- The same patient cannot check in twice
- Only patients with appointments today can check in
- If a patient has 2 appointments on the same day, nothing untoward happens, they are simply checked in for both simultaneously. The only time I can think of this happening is, for example, if they have an appointment with the Dr and then the nurse, say for phlebotomy services. Maybe the community can clarify for me?
-  This feature can be enabled and disabled via the global preferences pane.

**Documentation**
I am working on docs - just let me know where to send them/post them. Not sure if they need to go in the wiki/user guide or whereever?

**Screenshots**
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/x8te9ba23c5iaa0/AAComgUSKMv5bvyG80rBMWcHa?dl=0 

**Demo**
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Gamma_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

Also Needed to handle the cases where sortby and sortorder are passed in the request, but are empty.

I know this was already pulled into the master.  Just explaining what was going on here for historical purpose.

split is deprecated
http://php.net/manual/en/function.split.php
Should use either explode or preg_split instead.
I believe that
$mods = preg_split("/[: ]/",trim($this->procs[$prockey]['modifier']));
will actually make it so that both ":" or space will work.  That way we also don't break this for yourika who provided guidance on this.

Even though ":" was documented as the delimiter to use for multiple modifiers, it really wasn't correct since doing so would have resulted in incorrect CMS1500 claims.  This should handle both scenarios, where if a practice was primarily using CMS1500 and using space, their X12 claims would now work, and if they were using colon for X12 claims, their CMS1500 would now be valid.
It would be nice if the comments were consistent with the code. (144 chars limit specified in comment, but 255 in code)
Two a's in Start?

Not a big deal, but when people who have already patched/upgraded before upgrade again they are going to have both the pid index AND pid_encounter index which will be redundant .  Won't break anything, but MySQL will have to work ever so slightly harder  and use more space than if only the one index exist.

issue_comments.body: Ah, I thought Github was the primary now. I will pay better attention next time.

The problem only occurs when you're using the new CMS1500 (02/12) and an old claim.  OpenEMR now includes the code type with the diagnosis when justifying a code.  When the code type is included, it is stored in $code_data[0], and the actual code is stored in $code_data[1].  When the type is not included, the actual code is stored in $code_data[0].  When using the new CMS1500 (and therefore not stripping periods) OpenEMR would still look for the code in $code_data[1].

You'll also note that this throws off the diagnosis pointer.

Before Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731610/c2754c8c-c62f-11e3-9e14-764d1605ad66.png)

After Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731620/d85c1256-c62f-11e3-99f5-e047f8fed314.png)

@bradymiller I added the styling back to the HTML file so that users would be able to modify it easily. The forcing of UTF-8 does nothing, as when the page is served over HTTP the `charset` attribute in the HTTP `Content-Type` response dictates what encoding to use. The UTF-8 encoding would only be forced when that page is saved and accessed locally.
@bradymiller Fixed that error, I had just styled it wrong. Everything else looks good compared to the to Dev Demo.
@bradymiller Anytime! Does this pull request get merged too?

issues.title: QA DICOM Web Viewer i18nLocalesPath Integration
Support imaging with multiple images (CT or MRI)
issues.body: The issue is that the current dicom mechanism only supports 1 image. This is great for xrays. However, it sounds like this will get much more complicated for imaging with multiple images (such as a CT or MRI).

issues.title: Document reference isn't stored in the database when a patient has a very large pid
issues.body:
This bug is minor because it can only really happen from the use of another tool connected to the OpenEMR database (patient demo generator, for example, which has been patched), but basically when a patient `pid` is huge (e.g.: 99999999999), certain `foreign_id` fields in tables that point back to the `patient_data` table can't hold the value. This is the case with the `documents` table.

This would be a good first issue for someone looking to explore the code.

issues.title: Adding acl group to user on create/edit user
issues.body:
Hi.
Currently users that don't have the 'Administration ACL' permission can't add/edit user's acl group. 
This means that if a user has permissions to create users but does not have Administration ACL permission he can only create users without any permissions, which is pretty useless.
We think that the ability to add/edit a user's acl group (in the add/edit users screen - not in the acl screen) should not be part of the 'Administration ACL' permission but rather part of the 'Users/Groups/Logs Administration' permission.

pull_requests.title: Zbig01 backup update 1
pull_requests.body:
User interface improvements to the Administration->Backup along with a help script. Taken from the following PR:
https://github.com/openemr/openemr/pull/1235

Also fixes to the commandline restore script:
"The first thing that I noted was that whatever your database and openemr installation was called the recovered one would be called openemr. Secondly the restore script assumed the Web root directory to be /var/www/
I order to fix these problems I created a text file that contains the installation data, openemr-setup.txt, and modified the restore script to accept these values as needed. This now results in the recovered installation to be identical in all respects to the original. In addition the restore script is now included in the emr_backup.tar which now contains 2 archives and two files - openemr-setup.txt and restore."

Demo is here:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Epsilon_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

Hi garcianc,

The OpenEMR project does not use github to pull in code to the codebase (and none of the developers except myself will see these pull requests). To get the code reviewed and into the codebase, you need to post a link to your github commit(s) or branch(es) on the sourceforge developer forum:
http://sourceforge.net/p/openemr/discussion/202506/

Check out our developer documentation here:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/OpenEMR_Wiki_Home_Page#Developer_Manuals

Regarding placing new indexes, you add them to both the database.sql and 4_1_1-to-4_1_2_upgrade.sql scripts. Your database.sql looks ok. This is how would do it in the upgrade script (note that these comments are actually functions utilized by the upgrade scripts; see the top of the upgrade script for the function descriptions):

```
#IfNotIndex form_encounter encounter
CREATE INDEX encounter on form_encounter (encounter);
#EndIf

#IfNotIndex form_encounter encounter_date
CREATE INDEX encounter_date on form_encounter (date); 
#EndIf
```

thanks,
-brady

# Go to master
git checkout master

git reset --hard 24978cf2557ab527e83d7c58c6f1e48c6c8e842d
# Now overwrite your local branch master to your github repo (I am assuming you call it 'origin')
git push origin +master
```

And in future, when you want to feed your master from official codebase, follow these instructions:

pull_requests.title: Self checkin feature
pull_requests.body:
# Patient Self Checkin Feature

This feature allows patients to check themselves in for their appointment using a touch screen kiosk, for example this - (http://www.jayex.com/images/slideshows/patient-check-in//17in-kiosks.jpg) 
However, OpenEMR is web based - all you need is a web browser, so a spare iPad/tablet could be wall mounted and used for the checking in of patients.

The feature is found at http(s)://YourServerHere/portal/patient_self_checkin/

**Why is it useful?**

It frees up reception staff to answer the phone, deal with prescription queries etc. When the patient checks themself in, the same features are performed as when the reception checks them in. That is, the encounter is created, the status is updated to (@ Arrived) and the [flow board](http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Patient_Flow_Board) also reflects the time they checked in and starts the clock counting.

**Checks performed**
In an effort to ensure my code is as reliable as possible, I have performed the following checks

- The same patient cannot check in twice
- Only patients with appointments today can check in
- If a patient has 2 appointments on the same day, nothing untoward happens, they are simply checked in for both simultaneously. The only time I can think of this happening is, for example, if they have an appointment with the Dr and then the nurse, say for phlebotomy services. Maybe the community can clarify for me?
-  This feature can be enabled and disabled via the global preferences pane.

**Documentation**
I am working on docs - just let me know where to send them/post them. Not sure if they need to go in the wiki/user guide or whereever?

**Screenshots**
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/x8te9ba23c5iaa0/AAComgUSKMv5bvyG80rBMWcHa?dl=0 

**Demo**
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Gamma_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

Also Needed to handle the cases where sortby and sortorder are passed in the request, but are empty.

I know this was already pulled into the master.  Just explaining what was going on here for historical purpose.

split is deprecated
http://php.net/manual/en/function.split.php
Should use either explode or preg_split instead.
I believe that
$mods = preg_split("/[: ]/",trim($this->procs[$prockey]['modifier']));
will actually make it so that both ":" or space will work.  That way we also don't break this for yourika who provided guidance on this.

Even though ":" was documented as the delimiter to use for multiple modifiers, it really wasn't correct since doing so would have resulted in incorrect CMS1500 claims.  This should handle both scenarios, where if a practice was primarily using CMS1500 and using space, their X12 claims would now work, and if they were using colon for X12 claims, their CMS1500 would now be valid.
It would be nice if the comments were consistent with the code. (144 chars limit specified in comment, but 255 in code)
Two a's in Start?

Not a big deal, but when people who have already patched/upgraded before upgrade again they are going to have both the pid index AND pid_encounter index which will be redundant .  Won't break anything, but MySQL will have to work ever so slightly harder  and use more space than if only the one index exist.

issue_comments.body: Ah, I thought Github was the primary now. I will pay better attention next time.

The problem only occurs when you're using the new CMS1500 (02/12) and an old claim.  OpenEMR now includes the code type with the diagnosis when justifying a code.  When the code type is included, it is stored in $code_data[0], and the actual code is stored in $code_data[1].  When the type is not included, the actual code is stored in $code_data[0].  When using the new CMS1500 (and therefore not stripping periods) OpenEMR would still look for the code in $code_data[1].

You'll also note that this throws off the diagnosis pointer.

Before Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731610/c2754c8c-c62f-11e3-9e14-764d1605ad66.png)

After Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731620/d85c1256-c62f-11e3-99f5-e047f8fed314.png)

@bradymiller I added the styling back to the HTML file so that users would be able to modify it easily. The forcing of UTF-8 does nothing, as when the page is served over HTTP the `charset` attribute in the HTTP `Content-Type` response dictates what encoding to use. The UTF-8 encoding would only be forced when that page is saved and accessed locally.
@bradymiller Fixed that error, I had just styled it wrong. Everything else looks good compared to the to Dev Demo.
@bradymiller Anytime! Does this pull request get merged too?
Nope, it just gets closed.

issues.title: Document reference isn't stored in the database when a patient has a very large pid
issues.body:
This bug is minor because it can only really happen from the use of another tool connected to the OpenEMR database (patient demo generator, for example, which has been patched), but basically when a patient `pid` is huge (e.g.: 99999999999), certain `foreign_id` fields in tables that point back to the `patient_data` table can't hold the value. This is the case with the `documents` table.

This would be a good first issue for someone looking to explore the code.

issues.title: Adding acl group to user on create/edit user
issues.body:
Hi.
Currently users that don't have the 'Administration ACL' permission can't add/edit user's acl group. 
This means that if a user has permissions to create users but does not have Administration ACL permission he can only create users without any permissions, which is pretty useless.
We think that the ability to add/edit a user's acl group (in the add/edit users screen - not in the acl screen) should not be part of the 'Administration ACL' permission but rather part of the 'Users/Groups/Logs Administration' permission.

User interface improvements to the Administration->Backup along with a help script. Taken from the following PR:
https://github.com/openemr/openemr/pull/1235

Also fixes to the commandline restore script:
"The first thing that I noted was that whatever your database and openemr installation was called the recovered one would be called openemr. Secondly the restore script assumed the Web root directory to be /var/www/
I order to fix these problems I created a text file that contains the installation data, openemr-setup.txt, and modified the restore script to accept these values as needed. In addition the restore script is now included in the emr_backup.tar which now contains 2 archives and two files - openemr-setup.txt and restore."

Need to keep your master branch clean or things will go to hell (I am exaggerating a bit, of course :) ).

Don't merge into your master like this. Then you won't know what you are testing on on all the branches based on this. To clean up, suggest on your local repo doing following:

```
# Go to master
git checkout master

git reset --hard 24978cf2557ab527e83d7c58c6f1e48c6c8e842d
# Now overwrite your local branch master to your github repo (I am assuming you call it 'origin')

```

And in future, when you want to feed your master from official codebase, follow these instructions:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Git_for_dummies#Step_3:_Feeding_your_repository

pull_requests.title: Self checkin feature
pull_requests.body:
# Patient Self Checkin Feature

This feature allows patients to check themselves in for their appointment using a touch screen kiosk, for example this - (http://www.jayex.com/images/slideshows/patient-check-in//17in-kiosks.jpg) 
However, OpenEMR is web based - all you need is a web browser, so a spare iPad/tablet could be wall mounted and used for the checking in of patients.

The feature is found at http(s)://YourServerHere/portal/patient_self_checkin/

**Why is it useful?**

It frees up reception staff to answer the phone, deal with prescription queries etc. When the patient checks themself in, the same features are performed as when the reception checks them in. That is, the encounter is created, the status is updated to (@ Arrived) and the [flow board](http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Patient_Flow_Board) also reflects the time they checked in and starts the clock counting.

**Checks performed**
In an effort to ensure my code is as reliable as possible, I have performed the following checks

- The same patient cannot check in twice
- Only patients with appointments today can check in
- If a patient has 2 appointments on the same day, nothing untoward happens, they are simply checked in for both simultaneously. The only time I can think of this happening is, for example, if they have an appointment with the Dr and then the nurse, say for phlebotomy services. Maybe the community can clarify for me?
-  This feature can be enabled and disabled via the global preferences pane.

**Documentation**
I am working on docs - just let me know where to send them/post them. Not sure if they need to go in the wiki/user guide or whereever?

**Screenshots**
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/x8te9ba23c5iaa0/AAComgUSKMv5bvyG80rBMWcHa?dl=0 

**Demo**
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Gamma_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

The problem only occurs when you're using the new CMS1500 (02/12) and an old claim.  OpenEMR now includes the code type with the diagnosis when justifying a code.  When the code type is included, it is stored in $code_data[0], and the actual code is stored in $code_data[1].  When the type is not included, the actual code is stored in $code_data[0].  When using the new CMS1500 (and therefore not stripping periods) OpenEMR would still look for the code in $code_data[1].

You'll also note that this throws off the diagnosis pointer.

Before Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731610/c2754c8c-c62f-11e3-9e14-764d1605ad66.png)

After Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731620/d85c1256-c62f-11e3-99f5-e047f8fed314.png)

@bradymiller I added the styling back to the HTML file so that users would be able to modify it easily. The forcing of UTF-8 does nothing, as when the page is served over HTTP the `charset` attribute in the HTTP `Content-Type` response dictates what encoding to use. The UTF-8 encoding would only be forced when that page is saved and accessed locally.
@bradymiller Fixed that error, I had just styled it wrong. Everything else looks good compared to the to Dev Demo.

Support imaging with multiple images (CT or MRI)

issues.title: Document reference isn't stored in the database when a patient has a very large pid
issues.body:
This bug is minor because it can only really happen from the use of another tool connected to the OpenEMR database (patient demo generator, for example, which has been patched), but basically when a patient `pid` is huge (e.g.: 99999999999), certain `foreign_id` fields in tables that point back to the `patient_data` table can't hold the value. This is the case with the `documents` table.

This would be a good first issue for someone looking to explore the code.

issues.title: Adding acl group to user on create/edit user
issues.body:
Hi.
Currently users that don't have the 'Administration ACL' permission can't add/edit user's acl group. 
This means that if a user has permissions to create users but does not have Administration ACL permission he can only create users without any permissions, which is pretty useless.
We think that the ability to add/edit a user's acl group (in the add/edit users screen - not in the acl screen) should not be part of the 'Administration ACL' permission but rather part of the 'Users/Groups/Logs Administration' permission.

pull_requests.title: Zbig01 backup update 1
pull_requests.body:
User interface improvements to the Administration->Backup along with a help script. Taken from the following PR:
https://github.com/openemr/openemr/pull/1235

Also fixes to the commandline restore script:
"The first thing that I noted was that whatever your database and openemr installation was called the recovered one would be called openemr. Secondly the restore script assumed the Web root directory to be /var/www/
I order to fix these problems I created a text file that contains the installation data, openemr-setup.txt, and modified the restore script to accept these values as needed. This now results in the recovered installation to be identical in all respects to the original. In addition the restore script is now included in the emr_backup.tar which now contains 2 archives and two files - openemr-setup.txt and restore."

Demo is here:
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Epsilon_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

Regarding placing new indexes, you add them to both the database.sql and 4_1_1-to-4_1_2_upgrade.sql scripts. Your database.sql looks ok. This is how would do it in the upgrade script (note that these comments are actually functions utilized by the upgrade scripts; see the top of the upgrade script for the function descriptions):

```
#IfNotIndex form_encounter encounter
CREATE INDEX encounter on form_encounter (encounter);
#EndIf

#IfNotIndex form_encounter encounter_date
CREATE INDEX encounter_date on form_encounter (date); 
#EndIf
```

thanks,
-brady

pull_requests.title: Self checkin feature
pull_requests.body:
# Patient Self Checkin Feature

This feature allows patients to check themselves in for their appointment using a touch screen kiosk, for example this - (http://www.jayex.com/images/slideshows/patient-check-in//17in-kiosks.jpg) 
However, OpenEMR is web based - all you need is a web browser, so a spare iPad/tablet could be wall mounted and used for the checking in of patients.

The feature is found at http(s)://YourServerHere/portal/patient_self_checkin/

**Why is it useful?**

It frees up reception staff to answer the phone, deal with prescription queries etc. When the patient checks themself in, the same features are performed as when the reception checks them in. That is, the encounter is created, the status is updated to (@ Arrived) and the [flow board](http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Patient_Flow_Board) also reflects the time they checked in and starts the clock counting.

**Checks performed**
In an effort to ensure my code is as reliable as possible, I have performed the following checks

- The same patient cannot check in twice
- Only patients with appointments today can check in
- If a patient has 2 appointments on the same day, nothing untoward happens, they are simply checked in for both simultaneously. The only time I can think of this happening is, for example, if they have an appointment with the Dr and then the nurse, say for phlebotomy services. Maybe the community can clarify for me?
-  This feature can be enabled and disabled via the global preferences pane.

**Documentation**
I am working on docs - just let me know where to send them/post them. Not sure if they need to go in the wiki/user guide or whereever?

**Screenshots**
https://www.dropbox.com/sh/x8te9ba23c5iaa0/AAComgUSKMv5bvyG80rBMWcHa?dl=0 

**Demo**
http://www.open-emr.org/wiki/index.php/Development_Demo#Gamma_-_Up_For_Grabs_Demo

commit_comments.body:
Also Needed to handle the cases where sortby and sortorder are passed in the request, but are empty.

I know this was already pulled into the master.  Just explaining what was going on here for historical purpose.

split is deprecated
http://php.net/manual/en/function.split.php
Should use either explode or preg_split instead.
I believe that
$mods = preg_split("/[: ]/",trim($this->procs[$prockey]['modifier']));
will actually make it so that both ":" or space will work.  That way we also don't break this for yourika who provided guidance on this.

Even though ":" was documented as the delimiter to use for multiple modifiers, it really wasn't correct since doing so would have resulted in incorrect CMS1500 claims.  This should handle both scenarios, where if a practice was primarily using CMS1500 and using space, their X12 claims would now work, and if they were using colon for X12 claims, their CMS1500 would now be valid.
It would be nice if the comments were consistent with the code. (144 chars limit specified in comment, but 255 in code)
Two a's in Start?

Not a big deal, but when people who have already patched/upgraded before upgrade again they are going to have both the pid index AND pid_encounter index which will be redundant .  Won't break anything, but MySQL will have to work ever so slightly harder  and use more space than if only the one index exist.

issue_comments.body: Ah, I thought Github was the primary now. I will pay better attention next time.

The problem only occurs when you're using the new CMS1500 (02/12) and an old claim.  OpenEMR now includes the code type with the diagnosis when justifying a code.  When the code type is included, it is stored in $code_data[0], and the actual code is stored in $code_data[1].  When the type is not included, the actual code is stored in $code_data[0].  When using the new CMS1500 (and therefore not stripping periods) OpenEMR would still look for the code in $code_data[1].

You'll also note that this throws off the diagnosis pointer.

Before Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731610/c2754c8c-c62f-11e3-9e14-764d1605ad66.png)

After Patch:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3718499/2731620/d85c1256-c62f-11e3-99f5-e047f8fed314.png)

@bradymiller I added the styling back to the HTML file so that users would be able to modify it easily. The forcing of UTF-8 does nothing, as when the page is served over HTTP the `charset` attribute in the HTTP `Content-Type` response dictates what encoding to use. The UTF-8 encoding would only be forced when that page is saved and accessed locally.
@bradymiller Fixed that error, I had just styled it wrong. Everything else looks good compared to the to Dev Demo.
@bradymiller Anytime! Does this pull request get merged too?
Nope, it just gets closed.
